question: Knitting is a fully observable, episodic, stochastic, static and exciting agent environment.
Procedural attachment is used in semantic networks.
Ontology is not a key component in simple-reflex agents.
Recall is an evaluation metric used in information retrieval that measures the proportion of returned documents that are truly relevant
Simulated annealing is a local search method.
Term Frequency (TF) defines the count of a term t in a collection of documents.
A common heuristic function for 8-puzzle game is Manhattan distance which is the sum of the distances of the tiles to their goal positions.
If both H1 and H2 are admissible heuristics for a problem and H2 < H1, then H2 is a better heuristic.
An agent must think like a human in order to pass the Turing test.
Iterative deepening search is optimal if step-costs is a constant, the search-space is finite and a goal exists.

Suppose the following action schema in a planning system for 8-puzzle.<math display="block"><mi>Action</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>Slide</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>,</mo></math><math display="block"><mtext>PRECOND:</mtext><mo> </mo><mi>On</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mi>Tile</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mi>Blank</mi><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mi>Adjacent</mi><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math><math display="block"><mtext>EFFECT:</mtext><mo> </mo><mi>On</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mi>Blank</mi><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mo>¬</mo><mi>On</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>∧</mo><mo>¬</mo><mi>Blank</mi><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>)</mo></math>Which of the following needs to be removed from the action schema in order to get "number-of-misplaced-tiles" heuristic?

We look at a Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) with the three variables <math><mi>X</mi></math>, <math><mi>Y</mi></math> and <math><mi>Z</mi></math>. Let the domain for each of these variables be the set of integers from 1 to 3: <math><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>X</mi></msub> = <msub><mi>D</mi><mi>Y</mi></msub> = <msub><mi>D</mi><mi>Z</mi></msub> = {1, 2, 3}</math>. Let the following binary constraint <math><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></math> apply between <math><mi>X</mi></math> and <math><mi>Y</mi></math>, and <math><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></math> between <math><mi>Y</mi></math> and <math><mi>Z</mi></math>:<math display="block"><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub> = [(1, 1), (2, 1), (2, 2), (3, 1), (3, 2), (3, 3)]</math><math display="block"><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub> = [(2,1), (3,1), (3,2)]</math>After running AC-3, what is the domain of <math><mi>X</mi></math>?

We look at a Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) with the three variables <math><mi>X</mi></math>, <math><mi>Y</mi></math> and <math><mi>Z</mi></math>. Let the domain for each of these variables be the set of integers from 1 to 3: <math><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>X</mi></msub> = <msub><mi>D</mi><mi>Y</mi></msub> = <msub><mi>D</mi><mi>Z</mi></msub> = {1, 2, 3}</math>. Let the following binary constraint <math><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></math> apply between <math><mi>X</mi></math> and <math><mi>Y</mi></math>, and <math><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></math> between <math><mi>Y</mi></math> and <math><mi>Z</mi></math>:<math display="block"><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub> = [(1, 1), (2, 1), (2, 2), (3, 1), (3, 2), (3, 3)]</math><math display="block"><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub> = [(2,1), (3,1), (3,2)]</math>After running AC-3, what is the domain of <math><mi>X</mi></math>?

Consider the following (incomplete) game tree for tic-tac-toe. Tic-tac-toe is a two-player game where players "x" and "o" take alternating turns to place their respective symbols in an empty cell on the 3 x 3 game board, with the goal of getting three in a row (horizontally, vertically or diagonally): Which one of the following statements is true?
options: Player x is guaranteed to win
Player o is guaranteed to win
Player x can win, but only if player o plays suboptimally
Player o can win, but only if player x plays suboptimally
Either player can win, if the other player plays suboptimally
Neither/none of the players can win

question: Which of the following may be most useful in generation of a semantic network automatically from documents?
What is the primary drawback of hill-climbing search?
options: The search can get stuck in a local maximum
The algorithm requires a lot of memory
The search can get stuck in a global maximum
The result depends strongly on the temperature schedule

question: When we illustrate the Minimax algorithm, we use the symbols △ and ▽ for nodes in the search tree. A variation of the Minimax algorithm additionally uses the symbol ⃝ for some of the nodes. What does this symbol represent?
options: A second opponent in a multiplayer game
A game rule has been broken
An element of chance in the game
An estimated score, due to cutoff

question: Which of the following researchers did not participate in the Dartmouth conference where the name "artificial intelligence" was coined?
Which of the following is the main inference mechanism in semantic networks?
Which of the following would you choose as the unifier for <math>UNIFY(Loves(Per,x),Loves(y,z))</math>?
options: none of the above are suitable unifiers.
